conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged particle in both the magnetic and electric fields.
The particle is injected at the origin O with a velocity at a 45-degree angle to the y-axis.
The velocity components are v_x = v_0 / sqrt(2) and v_y = v_0 / sqrt(2).
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane and directed inward (into the page).
The force on the particle is given by F = q(v x B), causing circular motion.
The radius of the circular path is r = mv / qB, with v = v_0 / sqrt(2).
The time t_1 for quarter-circle motion in the magnetic field is t_1 = pi m / 2qB.
The electric field is directed along the negative y-axis.
The force on the particle in the electric field is F = qE, causing acceleration in the negative y-direction.
The x-component of velocity remains constant: v_x = v_0 / sqrt(2).
The y-component of velocity changes due to the electric field: v_y = v_0 / sqrt(2) - at, where a = qE / m.
At point P(3L, L), the velocity is directed along the positive x-axis.
At point P, v_y = 0, giving 0 = v_0 / sqrt(2) - qE/m t_2.
Solving for t_2 gives t_2 = mv_0 / qE sqrt(2).
The total time T is the sum of t_1 and t_2: T = t_1 + t_2.
Substitute values to get T = pi m / 2qB + mv_0 / qE sqrt(2).
The time taken for the particle to move from point O to point P is T = pi m / 2qB + mv_0 / qE sqrt(2).
